number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Rogue-likes: the randomized frontier.FTL's randomness makes for some incredibly entertaining gameplay as you attempt to make the most of your trip from one side of the galaxy to the other to save the Federation, all while being chased by looming, innumerable rebel forces.You will extermish pirates to varying degrees of glee and bitterness. You will guide that lost civilian to their destination, find out it was a rebel trap, and smile. You will relish every victory.You will have to sell that Burst Laser III so you can upgrade your engines. You will open that Mantis escape pod because you are desperate for someone who can board ships. You will lose the last bit of your ship's HP to an unfortunately timed missle. Failing to make it to the end of a roughly 6-hour playthrough is what makes your victories significant.FTL is visually very simple, a hallmark of its indie production, but as much as it could benefit from a bigger-than-1280x800 resolution or perhaps even 3D graphics, I love how I can run it on my integrated graphics laptop.FTL is a tremendous value and important landmark in the history of crowdfunded games. Were I to wake up in an alternate universe where I had yet to create a Steam account, I would buy FTL again, for around three incarnations, anyway.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2013
												Amazing game. It's a rougelike adventure where you are at the helm of a ship that is carrying information vital to the survival of the remaining Federation fleet; the last remaining hope for the federation after their crushing defeat from the Rebels. You will have your ups and downs, sometimes escaping death by less than a second, just to have all your success of escaping near death crush down on you when the next ship you encounter happens to be a Mantis war vessel armed to the teeth. You may lose and you may find the game to be a bit harsh at times, but it can be assured that you will always come back and try to save the Federation from the verge of defeat with what little is at your disposal, time and time again. 9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												133 hours and i still havent finished it! I will keep trying though! To begin ship selection is restricted to a single vessel but once they're all unlocked through in-game events there is a great selection, each catering to different playstyles. Combat is fast and unforgiving especially if your enemy has an advantage over your craft at that time. Having a level 3 teleporter and 4 mantis boarding crew with stars means nothing if the enemy is a probe with no atmosphere on board. Good micro-management during combat is vital and incredibly satisfying when you pull it off. Fires break out, systems go down and hull breaches appear all of which require crew to manage. There are also environmental factors to consider, like solar flares igniting fires or asteroid fields wrecking your shields. Upgrading your ship is easy and there is so many different upgrades you will be experimenting for a while. Different ships start out with different systems and new systems can be installed in shops throughout the game using the in-game currency: scrap. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												By far one of my most favourite games on here. This game combines tactics, luck and the Final Boss to challenge you and replay. Its replayability comes into play when youve lost and you realise you can just start again, no frustration required. This game takes you on a journey through 8 sectors where your quest is to gather materials and upgrade your ship in preparation of fighting the Rebel Flagship, and along the way you are plunged into problem solving situations for greater or less/unexpected rewards, achievements and new ship layouts.The Advanced Edition Expansion has made the game even more greater than it already was (if that exists). The features included are things like new systems and subsystems , new weapons , new race, Type C ship layouts and even a "hard" difficulty and other miscellaneous additions. This has added a new twist to the gameplay and a new reason for "fed up" players (somehow) to begin playing it again. But regular old FTL still remains with just the click of button.£6.99 GBP / $9.99 USD / €9.99 / 249 rublesHaving played nearly/already 100 hours , for me its a must buy.

												Ship log #4F-T55A7LWe were given something special to help aid in the fight against the rebels, Despite the Federations plight, we were it's sole hope of triumph.Throughout the kestrels travels many crew members had assisted in the fight against the rebel fleet in various battles through Engi space, to an uncharted nebula.But none of us could have foreseen the great doom that which was a mere science lab.Hidden beyond it's fancy air-lock were seven madmen in coats who had somehow turned the captain against the kestrels very own crew.Before the crew knew what had happened, the captain began punching Cubin and the rest had descended upon various subsystems.Amidst the battle two other crew members were taken from us, Tomas punched to death beside the FTL drive and Nelis asphyxiated in the weapons bay.Relentless with reckless abandon, the lab-coated madmen pursued Cubin and Martin to the med-bay only to suffocate and drop lifelessly in the mid-deck one by one.Cubin and Martin retreated to the medical bay fighting a losing battle, healing their asphyxiation in a now completely decompressed kestrel.This is the ships computer logging off.Rebel : These were the last recordings aboard the Kestrel, Should i delete them sir?Rebel leader : Oh no no, this is hilarious! But uhh.. what happened to the survivors?Rebel: We destroyed the med-bay and watched.*collective chuckle*Rebel leader : You're all promoted!10/10 would check a science lab again.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												This game is an experience. Pros:- The soundtrack is legendary. Probably the best in any game i've played. - The randomly generated story you get through this rogue like is good. - The gameplay is intense. You gotta manage your ships power and coordinate attacks while at the same time dealing with fires, hull damages, boarding crews, hurt crewmembers on board your ship. Nothing feels better than after a hectic near-death high-stakes battle jumping to a store to repair and hearing the calming music come on. - The game is brutal. Getting to the end is hard because there are so many opportunities for you to die along the way. You have to manage resources and plan ahead. Play throughs take time and with perma-death, every battles has high stakes.- Combine the music, the art, and the merciless gameplay, you get an awesome atmosphere to the game. - The game costs less than $10Cons:- The game's very hard to beat- The jump animation shoulda been a bit different: make it look less like teleporation and more like quick acceleration to FTL travel.- The final boss feels unneccessary. It doesn't add any value to the gameplay, only adds plot holes to the story line. What is the federation doing sending a tiny scout vessel to fight a huge rebel flagship? Even if it did send it, why isn't the federation helping out with any artillery volleys or something? Without the boss the game is hard enough. I give this game a 9.5/10. If they removed the final boss and to compensate added an extra sector to the map, FTL would've been 10/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2013
												If you don't own this game, frankly, you're missing out. It's an incredibly satisfying experience, and I get hooked every time I start it up. Expect to lose. A lot. But don't feel bad about it; dying is half the fun in this game! You learn better strategies as you keep playing (and inevitably being blown to bits), and once you finally beat the final boss... you're just on top of the world. I'm not a big fan of games that rely on luck as much as this game does, but this game is too much fun for me to care. ...Or at least justify having to care. It constantly makes you think and it rewards clever thinking. Just about anyone can have fun with this game; it's well worth the investment, even at full price.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												If you don't own this game, you are missing out. FTL is a true gem of a game, something playable by people of all skill levels, with enough challenge and replayability to provide hundreds of hours of gameplay. My ONLY complains is the lack of consistency. I get a surrender offer for 6 fuel, 4 missiles, and 15 scrap..... I kill the crew leaving the ship intact, and there's 1 fuel 1 drone part, and 30 scrap. And various other events where RNG rewards create weird situations. THE only complaint. Everything else about the game is pure gold, and this one factor is very minimal but noticible. If you are offered a good surrender, take it, the kill or freely scavenging rewards may not be as good. Other than that, best of luck and have fun! The FTLgame reddit is pretty active too, so visit there if you want to learn more or have awesome stories to share!

She was trying to escape from the evil guys behind her.That's basically FTL in a nutshell. It's a game that gives you a lot of fun, but also a lot of nervous breakdowns. number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Games such as FTL: Faster Than Light have been few and far between.  A proper rougelike, you never know what will happen during a run, and short of a proper ship layout, some luck, and a high level of skill, you probably won't get far often.  However, like any good roguelike, FTL isn't about winning everytime.  Too many games nowadays have no consequence for death.  This is all well and good in some ways, but we need more games like this one to make us genuinely try.As for the gameplay itself, I couldn't be more satisfied.  A mix of real-time and something like turn-based gameplay (you can pause the action at any time and set up what will happen next) give you the time to react to a situation as you see fit, but how you react and how it is timed is essential.  Will your weapon charge and fire, knocking out theirs before they can fire back; or should you aim instead at their shield room to make certain that your future volleys get through?  Will draining the oxygen from the engine room put out the fire before they are destroyed; or should you risk your men in the blazing room to put it out and keep that engine running?  Is that heavily guarded ship worth it, or should you sneak past?Enjoy your runs in FTL.  My advice?  Avoid giant spiders.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2013
												It's Dungeons Of Dredmor and The Binding Of Isaac but  in space. Faster Than Light is a roguelike game, meaning that if you die, it's truly game over. There's no reloading savegames, checkpoints, anything. You have to start all over again, except for a few things (like new ships or layouts) that you'll unlock during your games.The whole game is randomly created so you'll never play the same game twice. There's also a bit of micromanaging. Scrap the 'bit' part, in reality it's pretty important and you'll micromanage your crew in practically every battle. Your crew will have to repair important parts of your ship and setting them up correctly might make them reload your weapons faster, or recharge your shields faster. They'll even have to engage enemies in combat from time to time. Killed enemies will give you resources to upgrade your ship and buy stuff in shops. Stuff you desperately need in order to advance. In fact, soms of us might never even be able to complete the game, considering the fact that things are entirely random and it's also based on lots of luck. But it will never stop you from quitting the game. It's always fun, no matter what happens to your ship. You'll keep telling yourself; 'just one more game'. And isn't that what a game's supposed to do?FTL is a great game and anyone who gives it a try will absolutely learn to appreciate it. Maybe not instantly, but after a few games ? Absolutely ![Rating: 87/100]

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												FTL Faster Than Light is a rogue-like with the added twist of being set in space and based around ship management. The gameplay involves you mainly micromanaging your spaceship and crew as you travel through a number of random encounters trying to reach the other side of the map so you can deliver a warning to your rebel headquarters and defeat the final boss.FTL is a game that relies heavily on it's difficulty, being much shorter than your average rouge-like. You manage a number of fairly limited resources as you slowly improve your ship and crew. You gather fuel, missiles and money and hope for new and better weapons and drones as your crew members gain experience in whatever field they are working.It is a well made game and one I'm happily recommending but it's also a game that has some rather annoying limitations.Your ship has very little customization options which makes repeat playthroughs somewhat dull, an unusual trait for a rouge-like. Choosing a different ship often yields much the same gameplay as even though your starting position changes a little, the only real change longterm is the configuration of the various rooms on your ship.Another problem is the relatively short campaign you will begin to take note of once you've learned the basics and only the unforgiving higher difficulty gives it any sort of longevity.All in all FTL: Faster Than Light is a nice little game, but it is also a game that needs something more before I'll agree with the underdog hype that seems to be going around everywhere these days. Perhaps strong developer support and a growing modding community will one day make this into the game it could be but as it sits now it is nothing special.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												This game is a very well polished extension of the Roguelike genre. You pick a ship from a number of different designs each with their strengths and weaknesses, and are sent forth through a series of randomly generated star systems in the hopes of becoming powerful enough to destroy the Federation Flagship. However, instead of training a single character as you progress through the game, you improve your entire ship, its subsystems, its weapons and the crew within it.The game's charm lies within both its superb soundtrack which magnificently serves to highlight the action in the game, and its implementation of the game's different races and weapon types.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												This is a really clever game. The ship handling is especially cool, as you upgrade the ships features while also having to think of improving your generator to suit the more powerhungry merchandise you buy. You power each system at different power levels according to what's going on. You bombard enemies with a barage of deadly weapons to shut down their system. You maintain your crew and make sure to repair both combat systems and systems vital to your crews survival... In short, there are enough parameters in this game for it to be something you can be good at.If they made a sequel where they removed some of the random factor you face when umping between beacons, it would possibly be a perfect game.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												FTL is a game that covers every beautiful aspect of the gaming industry. The game is not too hard, but at the same time, not too easy. The random events gives different experiences on every journey, some good, and some bad. The game frustrates you at times, but at others it rewards you. The main mechanic that drives the game is the Permadeath feature. No saving the game and reloading it. There is no room for error in FTL, if you are destroyed becuase you didn't purchase better weapons, tough luck. It gives a feeling of individuality. When you are on the final sector of the game, you know this is it. One way or another, you'll never see your ship again, and it makes us feel sad for the poor crew. You have to manuever and plan out as the story progresses, or else you will be destroyed. Would I recommend it? Yes. I think it is one of the best Indie titles out there. With the new expansion, the game feels even more immersive then before. One of the best improvements was added customization, the fact that every journey would be even more different then before. I give this game a 9/10, one point deducted for the head-bashing boss, which I have only beaten once on easy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												FTL is one of those games that, if you don't dodge out of the gate, will grab you hard.  It's got that just-one-more jump thing, kind of like Civ.  It's got that mix and match build thing, kind of like Dredmor.  But what really makes it shine is the clever meshing of several minigames, all at once - but with the ability to pause and think about your orders.  Kind of like Baldur's gate.  But it's none of those things.  Instead, it's possibly the best spaceship game I've ever played.  Right up there with 4x treats like Sins and oldschool wonders like Escape Velocity.  It just nails that space atmosphere.It's a roguelike, it's a spacechip game, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ slot machine and you'll happily spend weeks yanking it's arm to fire up a new ship full of redshirts, optimistically hurtling to their doom.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game though.You don't really pilot your ship, you omnisciently control it - and it's tough. If you don't die in the first system your first time, then you are inhuman. The game is incredibly unforgiving, and EVERY choice you make has an impact. Stranded civilian ship want to trade 5 missiles for two of your fuel? You run out of fuel before you can resupply at the next store, and die. Refuse a pirate trader and wind up fighting? The extra hull damage to your ship causes you to explode in the asteriod field down the way. As unforgiving as the game can be, it challenges you to make smart choices, and manage your ship cautiously and conservatively.The combat is suprisingly fun, and the sound track is quite immersive - though I don't think I would buy the standalone sound track. Everything about the game keeps you coming back for more, and it's beautiful.

Posted: February 22, 2015
												FTL is a hilarious game where you control a spaceship and fight against rebels. This game just blows your mind with awesome moments. I'm not the type of player that likes singleplayers, but when I saw a stream of this game it seemed good. After buying it and getting more than 25 hours of gameplay I couldn't beat the game in easy. Even though its a really hard game you enjoy every moment you play. Everyone that had played this game remembers the giant alien spiders or having fire in all your ship. This are just some of the amazing memories this game gives you. Know it is time for the soundtrack, the soundtrack can't be described with words. Is just an amazing piece of work that improves the quality of your gameplay exponentially, the music makes you relax and enjoy each scene. It gets you pumped up when you need it and makes you think about buying the soundtrack of the game. If you don't want to spend a lot of money in games or you don't have a powerful PC I recommend you this game with all my heart. It's worth every penny, and you can easily get more than 150 hours if you enjoy the game. It haves a lot of scenarios, races, ships and 2 types of edition. If you get bored of the normal edition you can try the advanced edition. The game can be repetitive, but even after some time you get to enjoy everything about Faster Than Light.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												FTL: Faster Than Light is a masterfully crafted strategy game that is a love letter to any who find space adventure even the least bit compelling.  The game's core mechanics are gripping and harmonize perfectly with it's space opera theme.  Tension is built over the course of the game by limiting the player's resources and forcing difficult decisions.  Ultimately, the game crescendos to an amazing finale that will having you cheering out loud when you finally overcome it.  I recommend FTL to anyone who has even a mild interest in this type of game. And remember, dieing is part of the fun ;)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This is an amazing rogue like game for those who are patient. If you are fine with seeing characters and ships whom you've grown close to blow up in mere seconds, then do we have a game for you. The main joy obtained through this game is the feeling of gradual accomplishment that is recieved through each time you, unlock a new ship, gain another achievement, or finally obtain a successful battle strategy. The name of the game is to go through multiple playthroughs, each time unlocking something to improve your chances of survival in the next playthrough. There are many achievements gain, and an incredibly tricky final boss, so this kind of game will lead to countless hours of entertainment. It's a seriously enjoyable game... other than a few minor problems. One main frustration is the level of luck needed, and also  the matter of timing. You could be an incredibly good player and still get game-overed if struck with enough bad luck. The randomly chosen inventory type of the stores can cause some mild frustration especially if you seemingly can not find any stores that sells any useful weapons. Most annoyances in game can be worked through though, so there should not be too much frustration. This game is not for the weak of heart, and if you want this game be prepared to lose a lot. This game is not necessarily about the big victories, it's something that should be savored, but not completely suaght after. For those whole are willing to make the long and arduous journey, this game can reward greatly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2013
												This game reminds me a lot of a board game called “Battlestations” and it is in fact very similar. The game has many faces and I think that is why it has claimed many prices and nominations last year. You take control over a space ship and its crew members. You goal is to navigate through perilous star systems and avoid countless of rebel ships in order to reach the final destination and destroy the rebels once and for all. The game gives that certain feel of serenity, that people imagine outer space would feel like and at the same time it can be very stressful, testing your ship-management-skills and coordination to the fullest. It has various ships you can unlock, new crew members of different origin and species to hire, tons of weaponry and many different and unique encounters in the endless space that is Faster than Light.+ A new experience every time you play+ Arcade “easy to pick up” play+ Feels deep and complex, even though arcade style play+ Will last for decades to come- Adictive- Ruin free time with spouse

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Aside from Metal Slug, there aren't many pixel-graphic games that I enjoy. I know, I shouldn't go around judging games based on their graphics, and I don't. I just haven't played many pixelized games.The game itself is pretty good, it's rather strategic. The goal is to navigate your way to the boss, fighting through all sorts of randomly generated areas and enemy ships, with your ship. You have control of individual crewmembers, and those have different characteristics depending on what race (species?) they are. These crewmembers have different roles, all systems and weapons need crew manning them to be usable, and there has to be a pilot at the helm or your ship cannot dodge any attacks at all. Enemy crew can invade your ship, and your people have the ability to fight them off. Systems, weapons, and the hull can be damaged, and the crew has the ability to repair them all. While ship shapes are unchangable, there are a variety to unlock and some have special perks, and you have some options on what systems and weapons to place inside and on your ship, all of which impact your ship's combat capability. The boss is incredibly hard though. I've lost track of how many times I've gotten to it, but I've never beaten it once. It apparently has several stages, but I've only ever gotten past the first. In honesty, I'm not sure if $9.99 is worth a video game like this. Don't get me wrong, I love this game, but there's not very much in it and repetitiveness, for me, detracts from the appeal of a game. (I'm really iffy about prices for games... I don't think any game ever will be worth $60, unless inflation drives currency there.) I'd recommend this at full price, if you can totally spare the money, but if it's on sale? It's a great deal.Another thing I want to note is the game's music. The game itself is enjoyable, but the music is on another darn level. There was a time when I'd plug in both of my ear-phones, search up the soundtrack, and listen to it with my eyes closed. It literally gave me goosebumps and chills. I'm no expert in music or music analyzation, but I think this needs an award for its music. (Steam Awards, darn it.)I don't review often. I think this is my second or third time reviewing, and this may just be me rambling like an idiot, but thanks for sparing time to read through this. Have a good day, evening, or night, and... uh... yeah... stuff.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												What is there to say about FTL other than it is an amazing game that can provide you hours of limitless fun. The wide range of weaponry allows for a variety of play styles and can keep speedrunners and explorers alike entertained. The real gem is the games combat system which allows for on the fly tactical decision making that can impact the fate of your ship and her crew, all at the slip of misplaced energy bars.The graphics of the game are charming, and allow for those with lower end computers to enjoy the same fun as people with more expensive rigs. While it may be a turn-off for some, the simplified blocky art style showcases the gritty and fearful nature of the game and what lies beyond the great expanse of space Procedural generation makes it so that no 2 adventures are the same, however the same cannot be said about the specific encounters or battles as they will inevitably repeat themselves. This can become annoying over multiple playthroughs, but overall will not detract from the game as a whole.In conclusion, I would reccomend this game to someone who has always wanted to be at the helm of their very own starship, or someone who just needs a casual breakaway from your everyday AAA-cookie cutter title.Rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												FTL is pretty much everything you see on an episode of Star Trek.  That's literally what it is; Star Trek: The Game.  Want to divert power from weapons into shields?  By gum, you can.  Want to use your scanners to avoid enemy ships?  A valid strategy!  Do you not take a deal with the Slugs because they tend to rip you off?  Well, depends on how much you need it.Officially, FTL is a rouge-like-like.  Each round is short, usually playable in one sitting, and will vary from every other round immensely.  With fantastic music and brilliant story situations, I would highly recommend this to anyone that sees games above a simple entertainment venue as well as anyone who wanted to be Captain Kirk when they were a kid.  Both categories of people, and many more at that, will be completely satisfied.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Let me just start off by saying that I adore this game any other roguelike I currently own. It's a fantastic piece of work that almost seamlessly melds roguelike and strategy that's unforgiving in the hands of a novice but nontetheless rewarding and worth replaying constantly. It has the best soundtrack of any indie game I've played thus far, and making it a dynamic soundtrack with idle and battle versions definitely helped that. The writing is also interesting and clever, and definitely making it worth a try for any fan of sci-fi. Advanced Edition, the recent free expansion, expands upon the game's content by at least a third and adds yet another reason to get back at it.Regardless, I've come to dread the end level. Strategy and luck seem to go out the window in favor of luck alone. Your only real hope at winning is having fully upgraded almost everything, and if you don't have the right weapons and/or equipment you cannot hope to last the three phases of the boss. The boss presents no surprise and beating it becomes pretty formulaic. The Advanced Edition upgrades help mix it up a little and make it just a little less mind-numbing, but it still puts a dent in an otherwise near-perfect title.9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to captain your own star ship and fly through the strange and dangerous depths of space? Well now is your chance but it is not for the faint of heart.In short get this, it is an awesome rogue-like space simulator and you will not regret it. Also buy the soundtrack too, it’s very catchy.This game is great fun. The ascetics are very retro and remind me of games from yesteryear. The gameplay itself is fun, challenging and highly addictive, you will want to play it through time and again. Even when the odds are against you, and they often are, you will want to fight on and try to be the hero despite your impending doom. The in game universe is already vast and highly diverse, you never know whether the next warp will be to a friendly planet, devastated space station or rebel ambush. The whole game is more or less procedurally generated so you never have the same experience twice, which keeps it fresh each time you retry.As the captain you manage what systems you have installed in your ship, what weapons you have equipped, even which crew members fly with you. There is even a basic rpg system for each crew member, so if they do die you feel a sense of lost. I remember getting very attached to the little guys.This game will kick your butt and laugh at you whilst doing it yet that is a price that is very easily paid considering how enjoyment you’ll get. This is a 100% recommend even at full price, on sale you would be crazy not to get this. And due to a recent update it’s even better. There are also mods that can be applied for an even better experience, I recommend the Captain’s editionHave fun ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Excellent game for the price. Despite the linear "plot" to the game (make your way through eight sectors of a galaxy and defeat the final boss), you are given a huge number of options in terms of HOW you tackle this task. Whether you use boarding parties, drones or just arm yourself to the teeth with powerful weapons is entirely up to you, and there is an excellent balance that makes these all viable options.A playthrough doesn't take too long, so it's the sort of game you can play (and probably finish) in a couple of hours, or you can try out different things if you have longer. This means that it's a great game to play in either short bursts or a longer session.The unlockable ships and hidden easter eggs are the cherry on the top that may well make you come back and play this game again and again- I know they did for me. I've now gotten 72 hours out of a game that cost barely anyting- and it's been a better experience than a few games five times the price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Oxygen is leaking through fist sized holes in a hull. Crew is fighting fire, blocked doors and enemy six legged soldiers. Fortunately assault drones are still cannoning enemy spaceship and you are gaining upper hand in one of the many battles in the FTL.You are a captain of the spaceship and micro management is all you constantly do in struggle to survive all the random encounters and events the game throws at you. Your journey is difficult, unforgiving and you never know what lies behind the corner (the space is full of corners).The space is also filled with old school visuals (great!) and simple, not disturbing music (ok). Your crew levels up and your spaceship gets upgrades. And there are other spaceships to unlock which adds to already huge replayability. But there is no (real) plot, no characters, no real immersion and unfortunately no big excitement. This game lacks soul.So soulless, but still well deserved recommendation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2012
												It's a hard game to describe as it is simple and deep at the same time. One thing I'm sure of is that this game is beautiful, engaging and very fun. Random encounters, random shops, random events and even random galaxies make every single playthrough unique. The gameplay revolves around your tactical choices of managing a ship and their crew members, you can even hire aliens or acquire them by different means and the ship is highly customizable. Most of the events always give you a choice, and you even get bonus choices if you have a specific alien, weapon, resources or other things, that's a VERY appreciated RPG touch. The battle is simple, yet harder to master, you need to choose where the weapons should be shooting, is it wiser to take down their weapons, their shields, or their drones? Your call, and keep some crew to repair the damage. Overall, I'm really happy about this title, the trailer was great, but the game inside is so much more, truly an indie master piece.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												This game is brilliant.It looks simple, and it is, very simple, to learn to play. Mastering it, however, will take a lot longer.The game revolves around your ship, fleeing Rebel forces and trying to reach the Allied Fleet. You start off with a few crew, some minor weapons, and few empty spaces on your ship for improvements and new systems. How you develop from there is entirely up to you.You can use your scrap to upgrade your weapons, turning your ship into a powerful gunship. You have the options of buying new, stronger, weapons as the you locate stores, or traders. Or, if you are really lucky, you'll just find a random weapon floating in space.Or, perhaps you'd like to capture enemy ships instead of destroying them. Then you want teleporters, and Mantis crewmen. Mantis are the insectoid race, and they are excellent in combat. Beam them into your enemy's ship, and watch as they tear through the crew until the ship is yours.Of course, these are just two of the ways you can play this. With the Advanced Edition upgrade, you get new systems to play with, which provide you with even more options.On top of all this, there is the hangar. Even if you beat the boss, there are another 9 ship classes to check out, and most of those have three variants, so there is still loads to do.Then you have the various quests and missions to do, 8 randomly generated sectors of space to explore in each game, and even the chance of discovering a lost lost system... If you are lucky. All while on the run from the Rebel Fleet.In short, I highly recommend this game. FTL is loads of fun, and rather addictive. And even if you do get tired of playing (eventually), there are many, many mods out there for it which will change up your gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Having played FTL through multiple times, and fallen in love with the game over and over, I can officially say you should take what I'm about to say with a grain of salt. With that out of the way, I love this game.StoryThe story of FTL is a simple, yet effective one, providing just enough backstory to set the player into the universe. The galaxy was controlled by the Federation, a coalition between humans and various other races, such as the robotic Engi, and the hyper-intelligent Zoltans, until the Rebellion came. Humans were fed up with being equal with other races, and led a successful rebellion against the Federation, all but destroying it. You are the commander of a small Federation cruiser, holding the only information that can help the Federation win the war. Your task is to fly through the galaxy, racing against the Rebels, to get to the last Federation base, and inform them of the weakness of the Rebel fleet.Gameplay:FTL is played from a top-down perspective, with you, the player, in control of a spaceship, requiring you to manage weapons, shields, engines, etc. to keep the ship alive in the depths of an unforgiving galaxy. When I say unforgiving, I mean unforgiving.  Just about everything is out to get you: Pirates, Rebel Ships, and Giant Alien Spiders make up only a tiny portion of the people who want to tear your ship apart peice by peice. You have to survive the constant onslaught with just your wits, carefully balancing your systems and crew to quickly end conflicts with as little damage as possible. In between events, you jump from point to point on a map of your current sector, which can hold shops, distress signals, and other miscellaneous warp points. As you travel through the galaxy, you'll acquire new crew, weapons, and systems to fight the ever-stronger enemies, in an arms race to the Federation Base, culminating into a final boss fight that will put your ship, and your skills, to the test. This game is not easy by any stretch of the imagination, and even on easy mode you will find yourself dying over and over. If you can get past the difficulty curve of the game, you'll find that it offers a very deep and rewarding experience, which will keep you coming back time and again.Visuals:The visuals in FTL are simplisitic, and two-dimensional, this doesn't mean that they are bad however. The game's art is fantastic, with the various ships, weapons, and aliens all having a unique look that suits their particular traits. The environments in this game are gorgious, with backgrounds of deep space, nebulae, and planets that never seem to get old.Writing:FTL's writing is funny, adding a bit of levity to an overall tense game. Many of the random events are incredibly out in left field, and the writing capitalizes on this, such as in the case of the aforementioned Giant Spiders. That said, the writing isn't all jokes, and also does a fantastic job of building the universe. In many of the encounters you are offered a chance to let enemy ships surrender, with really humanizes each encounter, and provides a moral dillemma with each ship you encounter. Often the rebels really aren't that dedicated to the cause, and are just average joes conscripted to help, and whether you should kill them or not is up to you.Music:One of the best aspects of this game is it's sound design. This game has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a video game, with beautiful ambient music to accompany the lulls in the action, and tense tracks during tough battles. All the music in FTL is very electronic, most easily described as a mix of Chiptune, Ambient, and Trance. The music is relaxing enough to play a long session without getting boring, and engaging enough to keep you on the edge of your seat during some of the harder fights in the game. The sound effects of the various weapons, crew, and environmental hazards all fit perfectly, and can repeat without ever sound grating or annoying. Overall, the sounds and music in FTL add just as much to the experience as the visuals, if not a bit more.Problems:For all that I've said about the game being fantastic, it does have a bit of a flaw that some people may find irritating. The way you unlock ships straddles the border between a good progress system, and an annoying grind, especially with many of the type B or random event ships. To unlock Type B cruisers, you must complete two of the corresponding ship's achievements, which can be anything from a normal run, to a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ (I'm looking at you Rock Cruiser.) On top of that, there's a secret ship owned by the crystal race which has two methods of unlocking: Complete a series of random events, dependent upon about fifty thousand different dice rolls going perfectly, or beat the game with every other ship's (excluding the new Lanius cruiser) Type A and Type B configurations.  That said, none of the ships are objectively better than the others, and are really just built to suit different playstyles.Final Thoughts:FTL is a great game that will provide hours of entertainment, for a bargain price of $10, about the same as going to a movie. If you feel that FTL might not be the game for you, I recommend waiting until it goes on sale to try it. For those of you intrigued by the concept of a spaceship simulator, or like strategy games, buy it. You won't be disappointed.

In many of the encounters you are offered a chance to let enemy ships surrender, with really humanizes each encounter, and provides a moral dillemma with each ship you encounter. Often the rebels really aren't that dedicated to the cause, and are just average joes conscripted to help, and whether you should kill them or not is up to you.Music:One of the best aspects of this game is it's sound design. This game has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a video game, with beautiful ambient music to accompany the lulls in the action, and tense tracks during tough battles. All the music in FTL is very electronic, most easily described as a mix of Chiptune, Ambient, and Trance. The music is relaxing enough to play a long session without getting boring, and engaging enough to keep you on the edge of your seat during some of the harder fights in the game. The sound effects of the various weapons, crew, and environmental hazards all fit perfectly, and can repeat without ever sound grating or annoying. Overall, the sounds and music in FTL add just as much to the experience as the visuals, if not a bit more.Problems:For all that I've said about the game being fantastic, it does have a bit of a flaw that some people may find irritating. The way you unlock ships straddles the border between a good progress system, and an annoying grind, especially with many of the type B or random event ships. To unlock Type B cruisers, you must complete two of the corresponding ship's achievements, which can be anything from a normal run, to a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ (I'm looking at you Rock Cruiser.) On top of that, there's a secret ship owned by the crystal race which has two methods of unlocking: Complete a series of random events, dependent upon about fifty thousand different dice rolls going perfectly, or beat the game with every other ship's (excluding the new Lanius cruiser) Type A and Type B configurations.  That said, none of the ships are objectively better than the others, and are really just built to suit different playstyles.Final Thoughts:FTL is a great game that will provide hours of entertainment, for a bargain price of $10, about the same as going to a movie. If you feel that FTL might not be the game for you, I recommend waiting until it goes on sale to try it. For those of you intrigued by the concept of a spaceship simulator, or like strategy games, buy it. You won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												When strategy meets action, there's a slim chance for success. FTL doesn't know what a no-win situation is, and smashes through the gaming barrier of the two genres with pinpoint accuracy. This game belongs in your library. Here's why:Space. The final frontier. These are the voyages of you in a tiny little vessel struggling to stay ahead of a fleet that is gunning for you with big, nasty battle-cruisers capable of vaporizing your ship and your crew with it....but not if you're clever.FTL puts you in the seat of the captain, granting you the freedom to wage war, (or not) at your discretion. You place people at the con, promote others to chief engineer, or grant them control over the weapon systems. It's up to you, and their lives are riding on your ability to think on your feet. If you've ever seen an episode of Star Trek, you know that things don't ever go the way you plan them to. The same applies here. Should you grant sanctuary to a rogue mantis? Will you risk the lives of your crew to stop a fire spreading on a colony? Dare you grant mercy to the crew of the warships trying to kill you?The choices are real, and the consequences can come back to haunt you on your next jump. So many times have I been stuck staring at the screen, with the grim understanding that I've just backed myself into a corner. However improbable though, your split-second decisions can turn the tide of war in your favor, yielding great riches or rare devices for your ship.The soundtrack is stimulating. With a score by Ben Prunty that not only keeps you pumped, but grants that delightful sense of immersion through ambience, you'll be wanting the OST by the end of your first playthrough. Invest in the soundtrack bundle.The dialogue is believable, and well-crafted. You'll never meet a situation that you're bored by, as you meet not only malicious bounty hunters, but obscure traders who sell black-market goods in the dark corners of the galaxy. With the ability to name and customize your crew, the chance to lose yourself in the cast of your very own sci-fi thriller is quite likely.You'll get attached to ships. You'll invest great time and effort into crafting the perfect frigate or cruiser, stealth bomber or invasion drop-ship as you find new and creative ways to travel the universe. You'll regret losing crew-mates, and you'll feel genuine rage at the overwhelmingly intelligent AI as they access the weaknesses of your vessel and turn your ship into a bucket of holes.Most of all though; you'll never look back and question that this game was money well-spent. FTL is a must-have for any person who wants to get infinite-replay value on the bridge of a starship. Don't take my word for it though...*points ahead*Thrusters on full.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												When I first played this game I must admit that it was not the file obtained from Steam that I was using.  However, after playing FTL for a while it has become one of my favourite games and the effort that has been put into creating this game is immense, so evident in fact that I bought the game because the developers simply deserve it.  Through an intoxicating mix of luck, strategy, and permadeath, this game presents players with countless scenarios and tools that can be used to progress throughout the galaxy.  The gameplay is incredible and very rogue-esque allowing for a modern incarnation of a game viewed as a classic by many.  The atmosphere generated by the universe of the game encourages great immersion and the soundtrack within FTL is one of the best I have ever heard.  Oh, and kudos to Subset Games for their uncommon chivalry in making a huge expansion pack for the game free to all players.  This sort of thing is not seen much anymore and it is a testament to just how much the developers care about the players who have invested in this amazing experience.  I am looking forward to any new adventure that Subset develops and I will without a doubt be playing it.  FTL is an incredible game that achieves everything it sets out to achieve and more, the game deserves nothing less than full marks and I recommend it to everyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Aside from Metal Slug, there aren't many pixel-graphic games that I enjoy. I know, I shouldn't go around judging games based on their graphics, and I don't. I just haven't played many pixelized games.The game itself is pretty good, it's rather strategic. The goal is to navigate your way to the boss, fighting through all sorts of randomly generated areas and enemy ships, with your ship. You have control of individual crewmembers, and those have different characteristics depending on what race (species?) they are. These crewmembers have different roles, all systems and weapons need crew manning them to be usable, and there has to be a pilot at the helm or your ship cannot dodge any attacks at all. Enemy crew can invade your ship, and your people have the ability to fight them off. Systems, weapons, and the hull can be damaged, and the crew has the ability to repair them all. While ship shapes are unchangable, there are a variety to unlock and some have special perks, and you have some options on what systems and weapons to place inside and on your ship, all of which impact your ship's combat capability. The boss is incredibly hard though. I've lost track of how many times I've gotten to it, but I've never beaten it once. It apparently has several stages, but I've only ever gotten past the first. In honesty, I'm not sure if $9.99 is worth a video game like this. Don't get me wrong, I love this game, but there's not very much in it and repetitiveness, for me, detracts from the appeal of a game. (I'm really iffy about prices for games... I don't think any game ever will be worth $60, unless inflation drives currency there.) I'd recommend this at full price, if you can totally spare the money, but if it's on sale? It's a great deal.Another thing I want to note is the game's music. The game itself is enjoyable, but the music is on another darn level. There was a time when I'd plug in both of my ear-phones, search up the soundtrack, and listen to it with my eyes closed. It literally gave me goosebumps and chills. I'm no expert in music or music analyzation, but I think this needs an award for its music. (Steam Awards, darn it.)I don't review often. I think this is my second or third time reviewing, and this may just be me rambling like an idiot, but thanks for sparing time to read through this. Have a good day, evening, or night, and... uh... yeah... stuff.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												People who think games like Dark Souls is hard have probably never played FTL before. This strategy game where you control a space-ship that is running away from the Rebel fleet in an attempt to save the galaxy is honestly one of the most difficult rouge-like's that I've ever played. There were so many times when I'd reach the final boss of the game with max health and soon find my ship completely destroyed in mere moments simply because they'd breach my defenses before I could even graze their ship. This unforgiving game only lets you have one life throughout the whole game, and finding that the game runs on the weirdest random number generator doesn't exactly make things a lot easier on the player. The different weapons and ships make this game a hell of a lot more interesting, as you constantly have to make changes to your every move throughout the entire game. One moment, you may be dominating a supply ship to the point where they try to flee; but they can't because you shot down their engines. The next, the exact same thing is happening to you. With the new Advanced Edition, the entire game pretty much was changed and rebalanced (Flak is the most OP weapon. Get as much as you can). This game deserves a 9/10, for it's only problem being that unlocking new ships is too vague for most people to get, and with it's weird random number generator it makes it nearly impossible to determine if "this gameplay will get me a new ship to use".

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												A rogue-like space mission in which you must deliver the last hope of a dying Federation in a marathon trip through several varied sectors. Your journey is restricted both by your limited fuel and the approaching Rebel fleet, so grinding isn't really an option. Each game should take around a half hour to an hour and a half and there is a nearly endless combination of weapons and modules to experiment with. Everything is controlled by very simple resources and upgrade trees, keeping the learning curve short. All great things which make for a great game. What I couldn't get over, and what drains a good portion of the fun out of this game for me, is just how random a rogue-like. It is nearly impossible to set a goal beyond survival and success. Various weapon combinations might excite you, but there is no guarantee you'll ever get a shot at testing them. The trade off here is, of course, that each playthrough is unique and if that's what you're looking for, FTL is perfect for you. However, if you look to strategy games for intense planning and not the fun a constant wrench in the works makes for, this might not be the game for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Not sure how to classify FTL in terms of genre or playstyle, as it's pretty unique. It's a roguelike space simulator where you control your crew and ship as you race through various solar systems towards the end game. An individual game maybe lasts an hour or two or until you die (can be much sooner), but while winning is the goal, trying out new tactics and combinations of weapons is the fun part of the game.You control a few crew members in a ship with various parts. You can assign a crewman to pilot the ship, one to control the ship's shields, and have a third crew rotate between manning the weapons systems and doing ship repairs. When you get into a fight, your ship takes localized damage that interferes with your ship's functions in every way. Thus, combat is a game of maintaining your ship and taking out the enemy as quickly as possible to minimize the mayhem they cause. Sometimes your ship will be boarded and you'll have to determine how to kill the enemy crew who are breaking stuff and attacking your own crew while trying to destroy an enemy ship that is likely still shooting you. The game has a million tactical possibilities every playthrough and is wildly popular.It's cheap, and if you've got enough patience to play a game where the journey is the enjoyment, not the ending, you'll probably like FTL.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Boy...This is a tricky one.I'm not going to NOT recommend it. It's a good game, that's for sure, and I don't regret buying it. I've only played 7 hours so far, but there's no doubt I'll sink in some more hours so... yeah, it's a good game.But it's really not as marvellous and great and perfect as some reviews suggest. For one thing, this game does not have "awesome random events". The game IS one gigantic random event. There's really nothing you can do that you are SURE will bring in positive or negative outcomes. This total lack of control feels refreshing at times, but it's more frustrating than anything else in my opinion. Some randomness is good, but to me, things get old pretty fast when everything works on a dice roll.Other than that, the game is pretty hard and unforgiving. Good change of pace, considering the amount of titles that get thrown at our face where actions have no consequences. So don't get too attached to your crew... you'll see them die soon enough.So... yeah. I like this game. But it's not the game of the century. It got so much praise that I guess I'm just a tad disappointed. Actually, I see it more as a time killer, kind of like Eufloria (yes, I did just compare FTL to Eufloria. Go figure).But hey, that's just my opinion. Grab it for 2 or 3 bucks on sale and make your own opinion, you probably won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												What is there to say about FTL other than it is an amazing game that can provide you hours of limitless fun. The wide range of weaponry allows for a variety of play styles and can keep speedrunners and explorers alike entertained. The real gem is the games combat system which allows for on the fly tactical decision making that can impact the fate of your ship and her crew, all at the slip of misplaced energy bars.The graphics of the game are charming, and allow for those with lower end computers to enjoy the same fun as people with more expensive rigs. While it may be a turn-off for some, the simplified blocky art style showcases the gritty and fearful nature of the game and what lies beyond the great expanse of space Procedural generation makes it so that no 2 adventures are the same, however the same cannot be said about the specific encounters or battles as they will inevitably repeat themselves. This can become annoying over multiple playthroughs, but overall will not detract from the game as a whole.In conclusion, I would reccomend this game to someone who has always wanted to be at the helm of their very own starship, or someone who just needs a casual breakaway from your everyday AAA-cookie cutter title.Rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												FTL is pretty much everything you see on an episode of Star Trek.  That's literally what it is; Star Trek: The Game.  Want to divert power from weapons into shields?  By gum, you can.  Want to use your scanners to avoid enemy ships?  A valid strategy!  Do you not take a deal with the Slugs because they tend to rip you off?  Well, depends on how much you need it.Officially, FTL is a rouge-like-like.  Each round is short, usually playable in one sitting, and will vary from every other round immensely.  With fantastic music and brilliant story situations, I would highly recommend this to anyone that sees games above a simple entertainment venue as well as anyone who wanted to be Captain Kirk when they were a kid.  Both categories of people, and many more at that, will be completely satisfied.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Let me just start off by saying that I adore this game any other roguelike I currently own. It's a fantastic piece of work that almost seamlessly melds roguelike and strategy that's unforgiving in the hands of a novice but nontetheless rewarding and worth replaying constantly. It has the best soundtrack of any indie game I've played thus far, and making it a dynamic soundtrack with idle and battle versions definitely helped that. The writing is also interesting and clever, and definitely making it worth a try for any fan of sci-fi. Advanced Edition, the recent free expansion, expands upon the game's content by at least a third and adds yet another reason to get back at it.Regardless, I've come to dread the end level. Strategy and luck seem to go out the window in favor of luck alone. Your only real hope at winning is having fully upgraded almost everything, and if you don't have the right weapons and/or equipment you cannot hope to last the three phases of the boss. The boss presents no surprise and beating it becomes pretty formulaic. The Advanced Edition upgrades help mix it up a little and make it just a little less mind-numbing, but it still puts a dent in an otherwise near-perfect title.9.5/10

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Having played FTL through multiple times, and fallen in love with the game over and over, I can officially say you should take what I'm about to say with a grain of salt. With that out of the way, I love this game.StoryThe story of FTL is a simple, yet effective one, providing just enough backstory to set the player into the universe. The galaxy was controlled by the Federation, a coalition between humans and various other races, such as the robotic Engi, and the hyper-intelligent Zoltans, until the Rebellion came. Humans were fed up with being equal with other races, and led a successful rebellion against the Federation, all but destroying it. You are the commander of a small Federation cruiser, holding the only information that can help the Federation win the war. Your task is to fly through the galaxy, racing against the Rebels, to get to the last Federation base, and inform them of the weakness of the Rebel fleet.Gameplay:FTL is played from a top-down perspective, with you, the player, in control of a spaceship, requiring you to manage weapons, shields, engines, etc. to keep the ship alive in the depths of an unforgiving galaxy. When I say unforgiving, I mean unforgiving.  Just about everything is out to get you: Pirates, Rebel Ships, and Giant Alien Spiders make up only a tiny portion of the people who want to tear your ship apart peice by peice. You have to survive the constant onslaught with just your wits, carefully balancing your systems and crew to quickly end conflicts with as little damage as possible. In between events, you jump from point to point on a map of your current sector, which can hold shops, distress signals, and other miscellaneous warp points. As you travel through the galaxy, you'll acquire new crew, weapons, and systems to fight the ever-stronger enemies, in an arms race to the Federation Base, culminating into a final boss fight that will put your ship, and your skills, to the test. This game is not easy by any stretch of the imagination, and even on easy mode you will find yourself dying over and over. If you can get past the difficulty curve of the game, you'll find that it offers a very deep and rewarding experience, which will keep you coming back time and again.Visuals:The visuals in FTL are simplisitic, and two-dimensional, this doesn't mean that they are bad however. The game's art is fantastic, with the various ships, weapons, and aliens all having a unique look that suits their particular traits. The environments in this game are gorgious, with backgrounds of deep space, nebulae, and planets that never seem to get old.Writing:FTL's writing is funny, adding a bit of levity to an overall tense game. Many of the random events are incredibly out in left field, and the writing capitalizes on this, such as in the case of the aforementioned Giant Spiders. That said, the writing isn't all jokes, and also does a fantastic job of building the universe. In many of the encounters you are offered a chance to let enemy ships surrender, with really humanizes each encounter, and provides a moral dillemma with each ship you encounter. Often the rebels really aren't that dedicated to the cause, and are just average joes conscripted to help, and whether you should kill them or not is up to you.Music:One of the best aspects of this game is it's sound design. This game has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard in a video game, with beautiful ambient music to accompany the lulls in the action, and tense tracks during tough battles. All the music in FTL is very electronic, most easily described as a mix of Chiptune, Ambient, and Trance. The music is relaxing enough to play a long session without getting boring, and engaging enough to keep you on the edge of your seat during some of the harder fights in the game. The sound effects of the various weapons, crew, and environmental hazards all fit perfectly, and can repeat without ever sound grating or annoying. Overall, the sounds and music in FTL add just as much to the experience as the visuals, if not a bit more.Problems:For all that I've said about the game being fantastic, it does have a bit of a flaw that some people may find irritating. The way you unlock ships straddles the border between a good progress system, and an annoying grind, especially with many of the type B or random event ships. To unlock Type B cruisers, you must complete two of the corresponding ship's achievements, which can be anything from a normal run, to a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ (I'm looking at you Rock Cruiser.) On top of that, there's a secret ship owned by the crystal race which has two methods of unlocking: Complete a series of random events, dependent upon about fifty thousand different dice rolls going perfectly, or beat the game with every other ship's (excluding the new Lanius cruiser) Type A and Type B configurations.  That said, none of the ships are objectively better than the others, and are really just built to suit different playstyles.Final Thoughts:FTL is a great game that will provide hours of entertainment, for a bargain price of $10, about the same as going to a movie. If you feel that FTL might not be the game for you, I recommend waiting until it goes on sale to try it. For those of you intrigued by the concept of a spaceship simulator, or like strategy games, buy it. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Not sure how to classify FTL in terms of genre or playstyle, as it's pretty unique. It's a roguelike space simulator where you control your crew and ship as you race through various solar systems towards the end game. An individual game maybe lasts an hour or two or until you die (can be much sooner), but while winning is the goal, trying out new tactics and combinations of weapons is the fun part of the game.You control a few crew members in a ship with various parts. You can assign a crewman to pilot the ship, one to control the ship's shields, and have a third crew rotate between manning the weapons systems and doing ship repairs. When you get into a fight, your ship takes localized damage that interferes with your ship's functions in every way. Thus, combat is a game of maintaining your ship and taking out the enemy as quickly as possible to minimize the mayhem they cause. Sometimes your ship will be boarded and you'll have to determine how to kill the enemy crew who are breaking stuff and attacking your own crew while trying to destroy an enemy ship that is likely still shooting you. The game has a million tactical possibilities every playthrough and is wildly popular.It's cheap, and if you've got enough patience to play a game where the journey is the enjoyment, not the ending, you'll probably like FTL.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Heavily addicting little RTS game with a beautiful soundtrack! Just think Oregon Trail set in the Star Wars universe and that sums up this game perfectly. It took several playthroughs before I realized the game has more depth than it first appears, with plenty of special conditions and tests hidden thorough the game to unlock new ships. Another thing worth mentioning is the mod support, there is extensive modding community with this game that have created customized mods, an easy-to-use mod manager, and the ability to even write your own missions. My favorite mod so far has to be the one that disables the pursuing Rebel fleet allowing the player to visit every planet along the way. But even then, you won’t see everything there is to see after a few playthroughs…

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Excellent game for the price. Despite the linear "plot" to the game (make your way through eight sectors of a galaxy and defeat the final boss), you are given a huge number of options in terms of HOW you tackle this task. Whether you use boarding parties, drones or just arm yourself to the teeth with powerful weapons is entirely up to you, and there is an excellent balance that makes these all viable options.A playthrough doesn't take too long, so it's the sort of game you can play (and probably finish) in a couple of hours, or you can try out different things if you have longer. This means that it's a great game to play in either short bursts or a longer session.The unlockable ships and hidden easter eggs are the cherry on the top that may well make you come back and play this game again and again- I know they did for me. I've now gotten 72 hours out of a game that cost barely anyting- and it's been a better experience than a few games five times the price.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												In my honest opinion, FTL is amazing.When it was the standard edition I thought it was pretty good, and I still put quite a few hours into it, but to me it felt like it was just a little lacking.  After playing through a few times, I had decided upon my normal strategy, and varied little through different play throughs.  That may not be a problem for some more adventurous gamers, but after finding something that worked I just wanted to stick with it.  For me, the advanced edition solved that problem.  I thoroughly enjoy the new race, the Lanius, although my favorite part is probably the expansion of the available weapons.  Missiles, lasers, ions and beams was a good start, but often I just wished there was a little more variety in those classes themselves.  I found myself always trying to find as many 'burst laser IIs' as I could, maybe with an occasional beam weapon.  Now, I really enjoy trying to decide between the chain lasers, normal lasers, scrap throwers and ion stunners, all of which I think add a great deal of new tactics and depth to the gameplay.  Overall, I think this game is very well done, totally worth the money, and the day they come out with an FTL 2, or let you battle your ships with other players I'm sure I'll be lost in deep space for a very long time.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game though.You don't really pilot your ship, you omnisciently control it - and it's tough. If you don't die in the first system your first time, then you are inhuman. The game is incredibly unforgiving, and EVERY choice you make has an impact. Stranded civilian ship want to trade 5 missiles for two of your fuel? You run out of fuel before you can resupply at the next store, and die. Refuse a pirate trader and wind up fighting? The extra hull damage to your ship causes you to explode in the asteriod field down the way. As unforgiving as the game can be, it challenges you to make smart choices, and manage your ship cautiously and conservatively.The combat is suprisingly fun, and the sound track is quite immersive - though I don't think I would buy the standalone sound track. Everything about the game keeps you coming back for more, and it's beautiful.

Well now is your chance but it is not for the faint of heart.In short get this, it is an awesome rogue-like space simulator and you will not regret it. Also buy the soundtrack too, it’s very catchy.This game is great fun. The ascetics are very retro and remind me of games from yesteryear. The gameplay itself is fun, challenging and highly addictive, you will want to play it through time and again. Even when the odds are against you, and they often are, you will want to fight on and try to be the hero despite your impending doom. The in game universe is already vast and highly diverse, you never know whether the next warp will be to a friendly planet, devastated space station or rebel ambush. The whole game is more or less procedurally generated so you never have the same experience twice, which keeps it fresh each time you retry.As the captain you manage what systems you have installed in your ship, what weapons you have equipped, even which crew members fly with you. There is even a basic rpg system for each crew member, so if they do die you feel a sense of lost. I remember getting very attached to the little guys.This game will kick your butt and laugh at you whilst doing it yet that is a price that is very easily paid considering how enjoyment you’ll get. This is a 100% recommend even at full price, on sale you would be crazy not to get this. And due to a recent update it’s even better. There are also mods that can be applied for an even better experience, I recommend the Captain’s editionHave fun ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												It is only now that I have a better idea of how to play this game.If I remember correctly, I bought it at release. I just couldn't get the hang of HOW to play it, so it frustrated me to no end. That's different now.Although it looks to be very straight forward and arcady, I think it definitely is not.You need to think about a combination of upgrades and weaponry that you want to try and collect.There is a lot of random chances going on per each event that you encounter, so anything could happen to your plans.I like it a lot. For me, it is the right blend of casual and depth.I feel the artwork is wonderful. The score is decent too.There are mods for this little gem, as well. I've tried the Captain's Edition mod. Not having mastered vanilla well enough yet, the CE mod makes it a lot harder. It adds a whole lot more content, though. And more depth to the choices you are faced to make.I'm sure this game isn't for everyone. In a sense it is a rogue-like, you loose the game if you die and the only saving there is, is when you exit the game entirely. The only loading that is available is when you want to continue a game.For me, that adds to the intensity. You gotta think about your endgame, right off the start. Am I gonna go down this way? Or the other? Will I try trading with this mercenary? Or do I suspect he will board me and damage my ship?The currency used is metal scrap. You use it to trade and to upgrade your ship. You'll want to gather as much as possible  in the first two sectors, spending as few as possible until you can get your first upgrades without losing your backup scrap for repairs. Which you might need a lot.There's different ships and most ships have up to three different layouts. You unlock these through specific events or beating the game with a previous ship.Each ship has it's own pros and cons, layout and starting equipment/crew. Adapt your strategy accordingly.Wholefully recommend!
